According to the 2001 census, Bala ranked 11th most

-speaking town in the country, with 80.1% of the town's population able to speak the language fluently. As with anywhere in Wales, visitors will encounter no problems conversing in English, though a "Bore da" (Good morning) or "Diolch" (thank-you) will always be appreciated.

http://www.ukrafting.co.uk/ Canolfan Tryweryn - The National Whitewater Centre

, Frongoch, Bala. Tel: 01678 521083. White-water rafting and canoeing on the River Tryweryn. The flow of water in the river is governed by a dam controlling the flow of water from Llyn Celyn reservoir, meaning that conditions in the water are predictable - though this does not make the experience any less exhilarating once you are actually on the river!

For a more sedate water-borne experience, it is possible to hire rowing boats, canoes and sailing dinghys on Bala Lake.
, at the southern end of Bala Lake, is the highest mountain in the old county of
(Merionethshire, the southern part of the modern county of
). Bala is the main centre for walking in both the Aran and Arenig mountain ranges, which are considerably less frequented by walkers than
to the south or the ranges around Snowdon in the north of
, and can therefore offer a peaceful days walk.

It is possible to fish Bala Lake from a boat or from the shore. River Angling is also available in the area.

makes the 9 mile journey to the village of Llanuwchllyn at the southern end of Bala Lake. This follows part of the route of the old

Look out for

, which is said to inhabit the deep waters of Bala Lake. Visitors can make up their own minds as to the likelihood of her existence. The lake does actually house a genuinely (scientifically verified) unique creature - the

), a freshwater fish of the salmon family. The Gwyniad is native only to Bala Lake and until recently existed nowhere else in the World. A project to introduce it to another nearby lake has recently been undertaken, to mitigate the risk of its extinction should some tragedy  (pollution or similar) befall Bala Lake.

address=Palé Estate, Llandderfel, nr Bala, Gwynedd, Wales, LL23 7PS. UK
content=Palé Hall is a privately owned luxurious Victorian country manor near Bala in North Wales, set amongst 16 acres of gardens on the edge of Snowdonia National Park.
address= Pale Wood Holiday Park, Llandderfel, Bala LL23 7RA
content=Palewood Holiday Park in Bala, Snowdonia has a beautiful collection of holiday homes set in stunning natural surroundings.
alt=Ty Newydd Bed and Breakfast Bala

content=Offering two double rooms, one with en-suite and one with its own private bathroom. Decorated to a high standard all rooms have a colour TV, wireless internet access with tea and coffee available on request. Off street parking is also available. Ty Newydd has a no smoking policy throughout.
